sen.j: 神武天皇（じんむてんのう、庚午年1月1日 (旧暦)（紀元前711年2月13日?） - 神武天皇76年3月11日 (旧暦)（紀元前585年4月9日?））は、日本の伝説的な初代天皇。
sen.e: Emperor Jimmu (January 1, the year of Kanoe uma - April 3, A.D.585) was the legendary first Emperor in Japan.
sen.cmt: 庚午年1月1日 のグレゴリオ暦が不明のため、そのまま訳しました。
sen.e: Emperor Jimmu (February 13, 711 ?B.C. - April 9, 585 ?B.C.) was legendarily the first emperor in Japan.
sen.cmt: 訳者は紀元前を紀元後と誤解している模様。表記を紀元前(B.C.)に変更。legendary をlegendarilyとし副詞で使用。
sen.e: Emperor Jimmu (February 13, 711 B.C. ? - April 9, 585 B.C. ?) was legendarily the first emperor in Japan.
sen.cmt: 他の記事と表記を合わせました。

sen.j: 在位は辛酉年（神武天皇元年）1月1日 (旧暦)（紀元前660年2月18日?） - 神武天皇76年3月11日（紀元前585年4月9日?）。
sen.e: He reigned from February 11, A.D. 660 to April 3, A.D. 585.
He reigned from February 18, 660 ?B.C. to April 9, 585 ?B.C.
He reigned from February 18, 660 ?B.C. to April 9, 585 B.C. ?
sen.cmt: 他の記事と表記を合わせました。

sen.j: 百歳を越える年齢、とても一人の人物が行ったとは思えない業績（後述）などから見て、実在の人物ではないとするのが一般的である。
sen.e: Judging from that he lived over 100 years and he did so many achievements (later mention) which was hard to imagine one person could have done, it is commonly understood that he was the nonexistent Emperor.

Judging from that he lived over 100 years and that he achieved too many results (mentioned later) to believe they were done by a single person, it is commonly understood that he could have been a nonexistent emperor.

Judging from that he lived over 100 years and that he achieved too many results (mentioned later) to believe they were done by a single person, it is commonly understood that he could have been a nonexistent emperor.

sen.j: 『古事記』では神倭伊波礼琵古命（かんやまといわれひこのみこと）と称され、『日本書紀』では神日本磐余彦尊（かんやまといわれひこのみこと）、始馭天下之天皇（はつくにしらすすめらみこと）、若御毛沼命（わかみけぬのみこと）、狹野尊（さののみこと）、彦火火出見（ひこほほでみ）と称される。
sen.e: In "kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) he is called Kanyamato Iwarehiko no Mikoto, while in "Nihonsjhyoki" he is called Kanyamato Iwarehiko no Mikoto, Hatsukuni shirasu sumera mikoto, Wakamikenu no Mikoto, Sano no Mikoto and Hiko hoho demi.

In "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) he is called Kanyamato Iwarehiko no Mikoto, while in "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) he is called Kanyamato Iwarehiko no Mikoto, Hatsukuni shirasu sumera mikoto, Wakamikenu no Mikoto, Sano no Mikoto and Hiko hoho demi.
sen.cmt: 日本書紀は初出なので括弧で解説を追加。
sen.e: In "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) he is called Kanyamato Iwarehiko no Mikoto, while in "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) he is called Kanyamato Iwarehiko no Mikoto, Hatsukuni shirasu sumera mikoto, Wakamikenu no Mikoto, Sano no Mikoto and Hiko hoho demi.

sen.j: 神武天皇という呼称は、奈良時代後期の文人である淡海三船が歴代天皇の諡を一括撰進したときに付されたとされる。
sen.e: The naming, Emperor Jimmu, was named by a literati in the late Nara period, OMI no Mifune, when he dedicated shi (a posthumous name) of successive emperors all together to the Emperor at the time.

The appellation of Emperor Jimmu was given by a literati in the late Nara period, OMI no Mifune, when he dedicated shi (a posthumous name) of successive emperors all together to the emperor at the time.

The appellation of Emperor Jimmu was given by a literati in the late Nara period, OMI no Mifune, when he dedicated shi (a posthumous name) of successive emperors all together to the emperor at the time.

sen.j: 天皇が即位した年月日は、紀元前660年2月11日にあたるとされる。
sen.e: It is said that Emperor Jimmu ascended the throne in February 11, A.D. 660.
It is said that Emperor Jimmu ascended the throne on February 11, 660 B.C.
sen.cmt: 表記を紀元前(B.C.)に変更。前置詞をinからonに変更。
sen.e: It is said that Emperor Jimmu ascended the throne on February 11, 660 B.C.

sen.j: これにより、2月11日は日本が建国された日として、明治6年（1873年）に祭日（紀元節）と定められた。
sen.e: Accordingly, February 11 was designated a holiday (Kigensetsu (the day commemorating the ascension to the throne of the first emperor, Jimmu)) as the day of foundation of Japan.
Accordingly, February 11 was designated to be a national holiday (Kigensetsu (the day commemorating the ascension to the throne of the first emperor, Jimmu)) as the day of foundation of Japan.
sen.cmt: was designated a holiday を was designated to be a national holiday に変更
sen.e: Accordingly, February 11 was designated to be a national holiday (Kigensetsu (the day commemorating the ascension to the throne of the first emperor, Jimmu)) as the day of foundation of Japan in 1873.
sen.cmt: 原文に抜けがあり、そのままでは意味をなさないので、 in 1873.をWebから補いました。

sen.j: 紀元節は昭和23年（1948年）に廃止されたものの、昭和42年（1967年）には建国記念の日として、祝日とされた。
sen.e: Although Kigensetsu was abolished, the day became national holiday called National Foundation Day.
Although Kigensetsu was abolished, the day became a national holiday anew called National Foundation Day.
sen.cmt: became national holiday を became a national holiday anewに変更。
sen.e: Although Kigensetsu was abolished in 1948, the day became a national holiday anew called National Foundation Day in 1967.
sen.cmt: 原文に抜けがあり、そのままでは意味をなさないので、Webから補いました。

tit.cmt: 統一リストにより天皇の場合はBackground

sen.j: 以下は主に『日本書紀』に拠った神武天皇の事跡である。
sen.e: The following achievements of Emperor Jimmu were mostly based on "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).
The following careers of Emperor Jimmu are mostly based on Nihonshoki.
sen.cmt: wereをareに変更。Nihonshokiは既出なので引用符と括弧での説明を削除。
sen.e: The following careers of Emperor Jimmu are mostly based on Nihonshoki.

sen.j: 内容が神話的であり、神武天皇の実在も含めて現在の歴史学では、そのままの史実であるとは考えられていない。
sen.e: Content of the book is mysterious and the story,including the real existence of Emperor Jimmu, is not believed as historical facts in history today.
Content of the book is mythological and stories, including those about the existence of Emperor Jimmu, are not considered as historical facts in historical science today.
sen.cmt: mysteriousを mythological に変更。歴史学をhistorical scienceとした。その他表現の見直し。
sen.e: Content of the book is mythological and stories, including those about the existence of Emperor Jimmu, are not considered as historical facts in historical science today.

sen.j: 『古事記』にも神武天皇の物語があり、大略は同じだが遠征の経路などが若干異なる。
sen.e: "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) also has the story of Emperor Jimmu, and summary is the same as "Nihonshoki", but the description about the route of invasion and others are slightly different from those in "Nihonshoki."
Kojiki also has a story of Emperor Jimmu, and its summary is the same as Nihonshoki, but the description about the route of expedition and others are slightly different from those in Nihonshoki.
sen.cmt: 遠征の用語をinvasionからexpeditionに変更。既出の文献から引用符、括弧説明を除去。
sen.e: Kojiki also has a story of Emperor Jimmu, and its summary is the same as Nihonshoki, but the description about the route of expedition and others are slightly different from those in Nihonshoki.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』『古事記』の神武天皇の記述は東征が大部分を占めており、詳細は神武東征の項目も参照のこと。
sen.e: Most description concerning Emperor Jimmu in "Nihonshoki" and "Kojiki" was about Eastern expedition, therefore, please refer to the term of Jimmu tosei (Eastern expedition of the Emperor Jimmu) for more details.
Most descriptions concerning Emperor Jimmu in Nihonshoki and Kojiki are about Jimmu tosei (Eastern expedition of Emperor Jimmu); for details, refer to the section of Jimmu tosei.

tit.e: The time when he was Prince

sen.j: 神武天皇は即位前は神日本磐余彦尊（かんやまといわれひこのみこと）といい、ウガヤフキアエズの四男（または三男）である。
sen.e: Before his enthronement, Emperor Jimmu was called Kanyamato Iwarehiko no Mikoto and the fourth son (or the third son) of Ugaya Fukiaezu.
Before his enthronement, Emperor Jimmu was called Kanyamato Iwarehiko no Mikoto and the fourth son (or the third son) of Ugaya Fukiaezu.
sen.cmt: 左括弧の右にあるスペースを除去
sen.e: Before his enthronement, Emperor Jimmu was called Kanyamato Iwarehiko no Mikoto and the fourth son (or the third son) of Ugaya Fukiaezu.

sen.j: 生まれながらにして明達にして、強い意志を持っていた。
sen.e: He was born with wisdom and strong will.
He was born with wisdom and strong will.
He was born with wisdom and strong will.

sen.j: 15歳のときに皇太子となり、長じて吾平津姫（あひらつひめ）を妃とし、息子の手研耳命（たぎしみみのみこと）を得た。
sen.e: He became the Crown Prince at the age of 15, then he took Ahiratsuhime as his wife and had a son, Tagishi-miminomikoto.
He became the crown prince at the age of 15, then he took Ahiratsuhime as his wife and had a son, Tagishi-miminomikoto.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』によると、甲寅の歳、45歳のとき日向国の地高千穂宮にあった磐余彦は、兄弟や皇子を集めて「天孫降臨以来、一百七十九萬二千四百七十餘歲（179万2470余年。
sen.e: According to "Nihonshoki", at the age of 45, the year of Yang Wood Tiger, Iwarehikono Mikoto, who stayed at Takachiho no miya in Hyuga Province, brought his brothers and princes together, and declared " Since tensonkorin (the descent to earth of the grandson of the sun goddess), about 1,792,477 years have passed

sen.j: 偽書とされる神道五部書のうち『倭姫命世紀』、『神祇譜伝図記』ではニニギは31万8543年、ホオリは63万7892年、ウガヤフキアエズは83万6042年の治世とされ、計は179万2477年となる。）が経ったが、未だに西辺にあり、全土を王化していない。
sen.e: (In "Yamato hime no mikoto seiki" and "Jingi fuden zuki" of Shinto Gobusho (Five Books of Shinto) which are considered to be the forged book, it is believed that Ninigi reigned 318,543 years, Hoori reigned 637,892 years, and Ugaya Fukiaezu reigned 835,042 years, came to a total of 1,792,477 years.), however, we are still in the west and not able to rule whole land.

(in "Yamato hime no mikoto seiki" and "Jingi fuden zuki" of Shinto Gobusho (Five Books of Shinto) which are considered to be forged ones, it is believed that Ninigi reigned 318,543 years, Hoori reigned 637,892 years, and Ugaya Fukiaezu reigned 835,042 years, then these came to a total of 1,792,477 years), however, we are still in the west, so we have not governed the whole land.

sen.j: 東に美しい土地があるという、青い山が四周にあり、その地には天から饒速日命が下っているという。
sen.e: I heard that there was a beautiful land in the east, where was surrounded by blue mountains and Nigihayahi no Mikoto descended there.
I heard that there is a beautiful land in the east, surrounded by blue mountains, and Nigihayahi no Mikoto has descended there.
I heard that there is a beautiful land in the east, surrounded by blue mountains, and Nigihayahi no Mikoto has descended there.

sen.j: そこは六合の中なれば、大業を広げて、天下を治めるにふさわしい土地であろう。
sen.e: The land would be the rightful place for expanding great works and reigning over the whole country, if the place was in 六号,
sen.cmt: 読み方および意味不明。
sen.e: The land would be the rightful place for expanding our great work to reign over in the whole country as long as it is "kuni" (a conquerable land).
sen.cmt: 日本書紀で「六合」とは天地と東西南北、すなわち支配の及ぶ範囲（国）のことで、読みは「くに」とのこと（出典Google）。その解釈で訳出しました。
sen.e: The land would be the rightful place for expanding our great work to reign over in the whole country as long as it is "kuni" (a conquerable land).

sen.j: よって、この地を都とすべきだ」と宣言した。
sen.e: For these reasons, we should make this place our capital."
Therefore, we should make this place our capital."

sen.e: Therefore, we should make this place our capital."

sen.j: 諸皇子はみなこれに賛成した。
sen.e: All Princes supported his declaration.
All the princes supported his declaration.

tit.cmt: 出現単語の先頭を大文字化（除く前置詞）

sen.j: 10月5日、磐余彦は兄の五瀬命らと船で東征に出て、速吸之門に来た時、国津神の椎根津彦を道案内とした。
sen.e: On October 5, Iwarehikono Mikoto went to the east with his older brothers including Itsuse no mikoto by boat and when they got to Hayasui no to, they hired Kunitsukami (gods of the land), Shiinetsuhiko as a guide.

On October 5, Iwarehikono Mikoto went to the east with his older brothers including Itsuse no mikoto by boat and when they got to Hayasui no to, they hired Kunitsukami (gods of the land), Shiinetsuhiko as a guide.

sen.j: 筑紫国宇佐に至り、宇佐津彦、宇佐津姫の宮に招かれて、姫を侍臣の天種子命と娶せた。
sen.e: After they arrived at Usa, Tsukushi Province, they were invited to the palace of Usatsuhiko and Usatsuhime, and let Usatsuhime marry their courtier, Ame no Taneko no Mikoto.

sen.j: 筑紫国崗之水門を経て、12月に安芸国埃宮に居る。
sen.e: In December, they stayed at Enomiya, Aki Province via Oka no minato, Tsukushi Province.
In December, they stayed at Enomiya, Aki Province via Oka no minato, Tsukushi Province.
In December, they stayed at Enomiya, Aki Province via Oka no minato, Tsukushi Province.

sen.j: 3月に吉備国に入り、高島宮の行宮をつくって3年滞在して船と兵糧を蓄えた。
sen.e: In March, they entered Kibi Province, then, they constructed Takashima Angu (temporary lodging built to accommodate an Imperial visit) and stayed there for three years and saved boats and army provisions.

In March, they entered Kibi Province, then, they constructed Takashima Angu (temporary lodging built to accommodate an Imperial visit) and stayed there for three years and saved boats and army provisions.

sen.j: 戊午の歳の2月、船団を出して浪速国に至る。
sen.e: In February, the year of bogo, he dispatched a fleet to Namihaya no kuni.
In February, the year of bogo, he dispatched a fleet to Namihaya no kuni.
In February, the year of bogo, he dispatched a fleet to Namihaya no kuni.

sen.j: 3月、河内国に入って、4月に龍田へ進軍するが道が険阻で先へ進めず、東に軍を向けて生駒山を経て中州へ入ろうとした。
sen.e: In March, they entered Kawachi Province and advanced on Tatsuta in April, however, since steep road prevented them form going forward, they tried to enter 中州 to go toward the east via Mt. Ikoma.

In March, they entered Kawachi Province and advanced toward Tatsuta in April, however, since steep roads prevented them from going forward, they tried to enter Nakasu to go toward the east via Mt. Ikoma.

sen.j: この地を支配する長髄彦が軍衆を集めて孔舎衛坂で戦いになった。
sen.e: Nagasunehiko who ruled this area gathered his force and started the war in Kusaezaka.
Nagasunehiko who ruled this area gathered his force and started the war in Kusaezaka.
Nagasunehiko who ruled this area gathered his force and started the war in Kusaezaka.

sen.j: 戦いに利なく、五瀬命が流れ矢を受けて負傷した。
sen.e: The odds were against them, Itsuse no mikoto got injured by a stray arrow.
The odds were against them, and Itsuse no mikoto got wounded by a stray arrow.
sen.cmt: andを追加。Injured をwounded に変更。
sen.e: The odds were against them, and Itsuse no mikoto got wounded by a stray arrow.

sen.j: 磐余彦は日の神の子孫の自分が日に向かって（東へ）戦うことは天の意思に逆らうことだと悟り兵を返した。
sen.e: Iwarehikono Mikoto, a descendant of the sun god, realized that fighting against the sun (against east) was to against God's wishes, and decided to evacuate his troop.
Iwarehikono Mikoto, a descendant of the sun god in his understanding, realized that fighting against the sun (against the east) was against God's wishes, and decided to withdraw his troops.
sen.cmt: evacuate をwithdrawに変更。eastの前にtheを追加。その他見直し。
sen.e: Iwarehikono Mikoto, a descendant of the sun god in his understanding, realized that fighting against the sun (against the east) was against God's wishes, and decided to withdraw his troops.

sen.j: 草香津まで退き、盾を並べて雄叫びをあげて士気を鼓舞した。
sen.e: They retreated to Kusakatsu and lined up shields and raised a war cry to raise morale.
They retreated to Kusakatsu and lined up shields and raised a war cry to raise morale.
They retreated to Kusakatsu and lined up shields and raised a war cry to raise morale.

sen.j: この地を盾津と名付けた。
sen.e: He named this area Tatetsu.
He named this area Tatetsu.
He named this area Tatetsu.

tit.e: Guide of yatagarasu (Japanese mythological big crow)
Guide of Yatagarasu (a Japanese mythological big crow)
Guide of Yatagarasu (a Japanese mythological big crow)

sen.j: 5月、磐余彦は船を出し、山城水門で五瀬命の矢傷が重くなり、紀伊国竃山で死去した。
sen.e: In May, Iwarehikono Mikoto sailed the boat out, but arrow wound of Itsuse no mikoto became worse at Yamaki no minato and he died at Kamayama Kii Province.
In May, Iwarehikono Mikoto sailed the boat out, but the arrow wound of Itsuse no mikoto became worse at Yamaki no minato and he died at Kamayama Kii Province.

sen.j: 名草戸畔という女賊を誅して、熊野に経て、再び船を出すが暴風雨に遭った。
sen.e: He executed the woman bandit called Nagusatobe, and sailed the boat out again but was caught in a storm.
He executed a woman bandit called Nagusatobe, and sailed the boat out again but was caught in a storm.

sen.j: 陸でも海でも進軍が阻まれることを憤慨した兄の稲飯命と三毛入野命が入水した。
sen.e: After his older brothers, Inahi no Mikoto and Mikeiri no mikoto were annoyed by their anabasis being blocked both at sea and ground, they drown themselves.
Being angry about the situation their anabasis was blocked both at sea and ground, his older brothers, Inahi no Mikoto and Mikeiri no mikoto drowned themselves.
sen.cmt: drownをdrowned（過去形）に変更。その他表現の見直し。
sen.e: Being angry about the situation their anabasis was blocked both at sea and ground, his older brothers, Inahi no Mikoto and Mikeiri no mikoto drowned themselves.

sen.j: 磐余彦は息子の手研耳命とともに熊野の荒坂津に進み丹敷戸畔女賊を誅したが、土地の神の毒気を受け軍衆は倒れた。
sen.e: Although Iwarehikono Mikoto went on to Arasaka no tsu in Kumano with his son, Tagishi-miminomikoto and executed woman bandit in Nishikitobe, his army was exposed to poisonous air of the God of Land and fell sick.

sen.cmt: woman banditの冠詞をaに変更。「倒れた」の訳を be struck down by illnessに変更。
sen.e: Although Iwarehikono Mikoto went on to Arasaka no tsu in Kumano with his son, Tagishi-miminomikoto, and executed a woman bandit in Nishikitobe, his army was exposed to poisonous air of the God of Land and struck down by illness.

sen.j: 東征がはかばかしくないことを憂えた天照大御神は武甕槌神と相談して、霊剣（布都御魂）を熊野の住民の高倉下に授け、高倉下はこの剣を磐余彦に献上した。
sen.e: Amaterasu Oomikami, who worried that tosei (Eastern expedition of the Emperor Jinmu) was making little progress, had a talk with Takemikazuchi no Kami, and gave a sacred sword (Futsu no mitama) to Takakuraji, a resident in Kumano, then Takakuraji presented this sword to Iwarehikono Mikoto.

sen.j: 剣を手にすると軍衆は起き上がり、進軍を再開した。
sen.e: With swords in his hand, his army stood up and marched again.
With swords in his hand, his army stood up and marched again.

tit.cmt: 表題用に表現を見直し

sen.j: 神武天皇76年、127歳にして崩御した。
sen.e: In A.D. 585, Emperor Jimmu died at the age of 127.
In 585 B.C., Emperor Jimmu died at the age of 127.

tit.e: Theory of Nonexistence of Emperor Jimmu
Theory of Nonexistence of Emperor Jimmu

sen.j: 神武天皇が即位したという辛酉の歳（紀元前660年）は弥生時代にあたる。
sen.e: It was Yayoi period, when Emperor Jimmu ascended the throne in the year of kanototori (A.D. 660).
It was the Yayoi period when Emperor Jimmu ascended the throne in the year of kanototori (660 B.C.).
sen.cmt: yayoiの前にtheを追加。A.D. をB.C.に変更。
sen.e: It was the Yayoi period when Emperor Jimmu ascended the throne in the year of kanototori (660 B.C.).

sen.j: 明治に入り、近代歴史学が導入されると、歴史は、同時代史料や、同時代史料に基づくと推定される良質の編纂史料に根拠を持つものによってのみ叙述されるべきだという原則が広く承認されるようになった。
sen.e: After the introduction of modern history in the Meiji period, the principle that history should be described by historical documents from the same period or good quality of compiled historical documents,which is considered to be based on documents from the same period, was widely approved.

After the introduction of the study of modern history in the Meiji period, the principle that history should be described on the basis of historical documents at the same period or compiled historical documents in good quality, being considered to have been based on documents at the same period, was widely approved.

After the introduction of the study of modern history in the Meiji period, the principle that history should be described on the basis of historical documents at the same period or compiled historical documents in good quality, being considered to have been based on documents at the same period, was widely approved.

sen.j: しかしこの原則を古代史に当てはめると、皇室の歴史を直接疑うことにつながる故に、長らく本格的な史料批判は行われないままであった。
sen.e: However, if this principle was applied to ancient history, this would lead directly to doubt the history of Imperial Family, therefore, historical documents concerning the Imperial Family had not been criticized on a full-scale for a long time.

However, if this principle was applied to ancient history, this would lead directly to doubt the history of Imperial Family, therefore, historical documents concerning the Imperial Family had not been criticized in earnest for a long time.
sen.cmt: on a full-scaleを in earnestに変更
sen.e: However, if this principle was applied to ancient history, this would lead directly to doubt the history of Imperial Family, therefore, historical documents concerning the Imperial Family had not been criticized in earnest for a long time.

sen.j: それでも早くから、初期の天皇が非常に長命であることや、紀年が古すぎることに疑問を持つ者はいた。
sen.e: But still, there were some people who had a doubt about the history of Imperial Family for the following reasons: the Emperors in the early had extremely long lives, or Kinen (紀年)(counting years from era) was too old.

However, there were some people who had a doubt about the history of Imperial Family for the following reasons: Emperors in the early had extremely long lives, or Kinen (dates of their reigns) were too old.
sen.cmt: But stillを Howeverに変更。Emperorsの前のtheを除去。紀年の解説をdates of their reignsとした。
sen.e: However, there were some people who had a doubt about the history of Imperial Family for the following reasons: Emperors in the early had extremely long lives, or Kinen (dates of their reigns) were too old.

sen.j: たとえば明治の歴史学者那珂通世は『日本書紀』の記述を批判して、記紀の紀年は「辛酉革命説」に基づく編者の創作であろうと論考した。
sen.e: For example, the historian Michiyo NAKA in the Meiji period criticized the description of "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), and said that Kinen of "A Record of Ancient Matter" and "Chronicles of Japan" was made up by the editor on the basis of "Shinyu-kakumei-setsu (a prediction of revolution in Kanototori of the Chinese astrological calendar)."

For example, a historian Michiyo NAKA in the Meiji period criticized the description in Nihonshoki and explained that Kinen in the Kojiki and Nihonshoki had probably been made up by the editor on the basis of "Shinyu-kakumei-setsu" (a prediction of revolution in Kanototori of the Chinese astrological calendar).
sen.cmt: the historian をa historianに変更。said をexplainedに変更。その他表現の見直し。
sen.e: For example, a historian Michiyo NAKA in the Meiji period criticized the description in Nihonshoki and explained that Kinen in the Kojiki and Nihonshoki had probably been made up by the editor on the basis of "Shinyu-kakumei-setsu" (a prediction of revolution in Kanototori of the Chinese astrological calendar).

sen.j: 日本古代史に真の意味での史料批判が展開されるのは大正期の津田左右吉を待たなければならない。
sen.e: We have to wait appearance of Sokichi TSUDA in Taisho era, before criticism of ancient history in Japan was developed in the true sense.
It was not until there appeared Sokichi TSUDA in the Taisho era that criticism of ancient history in Japan actually began to develop.
It was not until there appeared Sokichi TSUDA in the Taisho era that criticism of ancient history in Japan actually began to develop.

sen.j: 津田は記紀の成立過程に関して初めて本格的な文献批判を行い、神話学、民俗学の成果を援用しつつ、神武天皇は弥生時代の何らかの事実を反映したものではなく、主として皇室が日本を支配するいわれを説明するために述作された日本神話の一部として理解すべきであると断じた。
sen.e: TSUDA is the first person who criticized literature regarding the process of coming into existence of "A Record of Ancient Matter" and "Chronicles of Japan" on a full-scale, and concluded that we had to understand that description concerning Emperor Jimmu didn't reflect any sort of fact in the Yayoi period, but were mostly written as part of Japanese Mythology in order to explain the reason why the Imperial Family has ruled Japan, with quoting production of mythology and folklore.

TSUDA was the first person who criticized literature regarding the process of coming into existence of the kojiki and Nihonshoki in earnest, and concluded that the Japanes had to understand that description concerning Emperor Jimmu did not reflect any fact in the Yayoi period, but were mostly written as part of Japanese Mythology in order to justify the ruling of Japan by the Imperial Family, taking advantage of mythology and folklore.

TSUDA was the first person who criticized literature regarding the process of coming into existence of the kojiki and Nihonshoki in earnest, and concluded that the Japanes had to understand that description concerning Emperor Jimmu did not reflect any fact in the Yayoi period, but were mostly written as part of Japanese Mythology in order to justify the ruling of Japan by the Imperial Family, taking advantage of mythology and folklore.

sen.j: 戦前彼の著書は不敬であるとして発禁処分とされたが、戦後になって天皇制のタブーが解かれると、多くの歴史学者によっておおむね妥当な推論であるとして支持されるようになった。
sen.e: Although his books were banned for sale in prewar times as being lack of respect, many historians came to support his books as generally appropriate deduction after taboos of the Emperor system was removed in postwar.

Although his books had been banned for sale in the prewar time as the books lacking respect for the emperor, many historians came to support his books as an approximately reasonable assumption when the taboo against discussion of the Emperor system was removed after World War II.

Although his books had been banned for sale in the prewar time as the books lacking respect for the emperor, many historians came to support his books as an approximately reasonable assumption when the taboo against discussion of the Emperor system was removed after World War II.

sen.j: こうした経緯から現代の歴史学界では神武天皇の存在は前提とされていない。
sen.e: From these circumstances, real existence of Emperor Jimmu was not accepted in society of historical science in today.
Under these circumstances, existence of Emperor Jimmu is not believed to be a fact in the society of historical science today.
Under these circumstances, existence of Emperor Jimmu is not believed to be a fact in the society of historical science today.

sen.j: したがって神武天皇に関する説話は何らかの形で創作されたものであるとする意見が強く、崇神天皇、応神天皇、継体天皇、または記紀編纂時期の天武天皇を基に創作したとする「モデル論」も盛んである。

On April 3rd every year, Jimmu Tenno Sai (The Emperor Jimmu Festival) is held at the Three Shrines in the Imperial Court and several shrines, while an Imperial envoy goes to the Imperial mausoleum to offer a wand of hemp and paper streamers to the Shinto God.

sen.j: また、神武天皇から昭和天皇に至るまで、歴代天皇は皆、皇居の宮中三殿の一つの皇霊殿に祀られている。
sen.e: And also, all successive emperors are enshrined in one of the Three Shrines in the Imperial Court of the Imperial Palace called Korei-den (the Imperial Ancestors' Shrine).
In addition, all successive emperors are enshrined in one of the Three Shrines in the Imperial Court of the Imperial Palace called Korei-den (the Imperial Ancestors' Shrine).
sen.cmt: And alsoを In additionに変更
sen.e: In addition, all successive emperors are enshrined in one of the Three Shrines in the Imperial Court of the Imperial Palace called Korei-den (the Imperial Ancestors' Shrine).
